instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
Hello Everyone,

One of my customers brought me a macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> , board number <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. When I plugged it in I can see that it stays around 5.170V and amp goes up to between 0.27 and 0.388 and back to zero again. And it is on a loop like this. When I measured the 
CF505 on  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 1.5V Stable,
CF508 on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.5V Stable,
CF500 on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> = up and down between zero and 0.2V but it goes up partly and goes donw again partly (I mean partly every 1 second it goes down to zero then goes up 0.1 then zero and 0.11 and back same way down from 02.V)
CF402 on <SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> = between zero and 0.5 (same as CF500)
<RESISTOR>R8441</RESISTOR> on <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET_3V3</SIGNAL> = around zeroV
CC337 on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> = 0.001V
RF235 on <SIGNAL>UPC1_5V_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.13V
RF901 on <SIGNAL>USBC1_3V3LDO_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.0V

Just because of these I thought the problem is UF500 but do I miss something else or am I right? Want to check with you guys anyway.

Thank you for you help in advance.

Emre

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
Any history fault available?
What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>?

Check diode mode to ground on S2 power rails.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 91501, member: 682"]
Any history fault available?
What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>?

Check diode mode to ground on S2 power rails.
[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> keeps going up and down between 7V - 12V
<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> keeps going up and down between 2.9V- 3.8V
RC714 on <SIGNAL>P3V3S2_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> jumps from 0 to 0.025 on diode mode

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
Jumps in diode mode?
I hope you didn't check with power applied.

BTW, write directly into reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message: It is 0.676 on diode mode, my fault. Im sorry. It is so busy at the shop and customers took my head off today.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
Check diode mode on all big coils.
Also check for any voltage spike.

Should check diode mode on master/slave PMUs rails too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message: Okay will do as first thing in the morning and let u know.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
LC710 on <SIGNAL>P3V3S2_SW</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> gives ground on both legs on diode mode 
i have checked all big coils and all i found is the one written above
i have checked pmu rails seems no problem (i dont know if i did it right, i have checked them also on diode mode)
And when I measure it I can see small voltage spikes on LC710 too from 0.00V to 0.024 and back and again

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message:
Compare resistance to ground at LC710 with known good board.
If is pure short, something got burnt there.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2020 Macbok Air Stays On 5V
threads.message: I have sorted the problem out. First I took the LC710 our of the board and checked the legs on diode mode. And found the short line. And it was 3.3V leg. So Ä± took the board under thermal camera and gave 3.3V to that line and found shorted capacitor. Moved it away. Put the LC710 back measured it again and Yay no shorts anymore and back to live.
